On Nov 9, 2004, at 5:59 PM, Derek James wrote:

>
> On Tue, 09 Nov 2004 21:17:41 -0000, Kenneth Stanley"s
> <kstanley@...> wrote:
>> I was just thinking, it's possible someone already mentioned this,
>> but it might be useful to add a little noise to the *outputs* of the
>> network.  In other words, if it asks to zoom, make it zoom a little
>> more or a little less than it asked (i.e. add some noise).  If it
>> asks to rotate, have a probability of slight over or under
>> rotation.  Faustino Gomez from our group has shown that model noise
>> (noise added to actions) is more effective than noise added to
>> sensors.
>
> That's interesting, but counterintuitive.  Wouldn't that be like
> purposely degrading the motor skills of a baby that's trying to learn
> to walk?

In a sense yes, but the benefit then is a more robust walking pattern. 
One way to think about it is that by adding noise, you're forcing the 
network to learn a more general function instead of allowing it to get 
away with the  "simplest possible controller for the test patterns" 
strategy. It is somewhat counterintuitive, however its precisely the 
same thing as, e.g. the mutation operator in genetic search.

Ken: by the way that experiment sounds really interesting. Has Tino 
published a paper on it yet?

Joe
